metadata.description: Period characterization using temporal network stability analysis

input_segments.description: Time segments from shift signal detection

period_characterizations.description: Final period characterizations with network analysis

characterizations.topic_description: The dominant paradigm during 1895-1957 centered on applying statistical methods, particularly probability theory and information theory, to model and analyze language.  Representative papers like ‘Prediction and Entropy of Printed English’ and ‘A Statistical Approach to Mechanized Encoding and Searching of Literary Information’ demonstrate a focus on quantifying linguistic properties through statistical analysis – predicting word sequences, estimating language redundancy, and developing encoding schemes based on frequency distributions. This approach, exemplified by ‘A Set of Postulates for the Science of Language’’s emphasis on measurable linguistic phenomena, contrasted with earlier, more rule-based or structuralist approaches, laying the groundwork for later developments in machine learning and computational linguistics.

representative_papers.title: Prediction and Entropy of Printed English
representative_papers.abstract:
The article presents a novel approach to estimating the entropy and redundancy of the English language by utilizing statistical knowledge from native speakers and experimental data on predicting the next letter based on preceding text. It includes experimental results and explores the characteristics of an ideal predictor in this context.

Topic: linguistics, english, text mining, natural language processing, language, entropy, english language, language science, english study

representative_papers.title: Three models for the description of language
representative_papers.abstract:
The article explores various models of linguistic structure to assess their effectiveness in generating English sentences, concluding that while finite-state Markov processes are inadequate, more complex phrase structure grammars and transformational approaches offer a more powerful and insightful method for understanding language. It highlights the formal properties of grammatical transformations and their implications for language description and processing.

Topic: applied linguistics, morphology (linguistics), computer science, linguistics, structural linguistics, cognitive linguistics, language model, natural language processing, language, general linguistics, theoretical linguistics, semantic evaluation, computational linguistics, semantics, machine translation, linguistic theory, language science, language learning

representative_papers.title: A Statistical Approach to Mechanized Encoding and Searching of Literary Information
representative_papers.abstract:
The article discusses a statistical approach to improving the mechanized encoding and searching of literary information, highlighting the challenges of conveying meaning through written communication and the variability in individual expression. It outlines a systematic method that includes document analysis, vocabulary establishment, and the use of automated encoding and search techniques to enhance information retrieval in literature.

Topic: narrative extraction, computer science, linguistics, text mining, natural language processing, literary information, information extraction, machine learning, computational linguistics, data science, knowledge discovery, similarity search, machine learning research, search technique, document analysis, information retrieval

representative_papers.title: A Set of Postulates for the Science of Language
representative_papers.abstract:
The article presents a comprehensive framework of postulates for the science of language, encompassing various subfields such as applied and theoretical linguistics, cognitive linguistics, and natural language processing, while addressing key concepts like syntax, semantics, and language assessment. It aims to establish foundational principles that guide the study and understanding of language in its diverse forms and applications.

Topic: applied linguistics, theoretical linguistics, linguistics, structural linguistics, cognitive linguistics, natural language processing, language assessment, language, general linguistics, syntax, communication, computational linguistics, semantics, mathematical linguistics, linguistic theory, language policy, language science, language learning

representative_papers.title: Predictive coding--I
representative_papers.abstract:
The article discusses predictive coding, a method for transmitting messages by encoding the difference between actual and predicted values, emphasizing its applications in various fields such as computer science, machine learning, and cognitive science. It outlines the foundational concepts of predictive coding and sets the stage for further exploration of its mathematical criteria and efficient coding examples in the subsequent part.

Topic: computer science, knowledge representation and reasoning, algebraic coding theory, natural language processing, data coding, predictive learning, machine learning, predictive analytics, cognitive science, data science, computational intelligence, knowledge discovery, machine learning research, predictive coding, code representation

representative_papers.title: Automatic Recognition of Spoken Digits
representative_papers.abstract:
The article discusses a speech recognition system capable of accurately identifying spoken digits at normal speech rates, achieving an accuracy of 97 to 99 percent for individual speakers. It details the system's methodology, which involves analyzing frequency bands and utilizing a two-dimensional portrayal for recognition, although it notes limitations in performance with multiple speakers without adjustments.

Topic: automatic recognition, computer science, speech recognition, spoken digits, natural language processing, speech processing, automatic identification, spoken language processing, machine learning, human identification, biometrics, cognitive science, data science, language recognition, deep learning, speech technology, spoken language technology, machine vision

representative_papers.title: Summarizing paper
representative_papers.abstract:
The article by A. J. P. Martin discusses various methodologies and techniques in summarizing texts, focusing on fields such as linguistics, natural language processing, and information visualization, while exploring applications in journalism and communication. It emphasizes the importance of automatic summarization and multi-modal approaches in enhancing document analysis and narrative comprehension.

Topic: linguistics, content analysis, information fusion, text mining, natural language processing, information visualization, automatic summarization, document analysis, multi-modal summarization, communication, documentation, narrative summarization, entity summarization, journalism, narrative, rhetoric, language documentation

representative_papers.title: The Occurrence of Clustering in the Recall of Randomly Arranged Words of Different Frequencies-Of-Usage
representative_papers.abstract:
The article examines how the frequency of word usage influences the clustering phenomenon in the recall of randomly arranged words, contributing to the fields of linguistics, text mining, and machine learning by exploring patterns in memory and language processing.

Topic: linguistics, text mining, natural language processing, pattern discovery, language, clustering, machine learning, knowledge discovery, frequent pattern mining, statistics, machine learning research, document clustering, distributional semantics, different frequencies-of-usage, corpus linguistics, group frequency

characterizations.topic_description: From the 2000s onward, Natural Language Processing research shifted towards a paradigm dominated by data-driven approaches. This involved leveraging increasingly large datasets to train deep learning models, particularly those based on neural networks. A core element was the development of distributed representations of words and phrases (e.g., Word2Vec, GloVe, BERT), enabling models to capture semantic relationships. Crucially, the field embraced transfer learning, utilizing pre-trained models (like BERT) and fine-tuning them for specific downstream tasks. The emphasis moved from hand-engineered features and rule-based systems to automatically learning representations from data, with a strong focus on contextualized word embeddings and leveraging pre-trained models for improved performance across a wide range of NLP tasks.  The papers demonstrate this progression: ‘Word Representations: A Simple and General Method for Semi-Supervised Learning’ (2010) established the importance of unsupervised word embeddings, while ‘BERT: Pre-training of Deep Bidirectional Transformers for Language Understanding’ (2018) exemplifies the paradigm’s culmination with large-scale pre-training and transfer learning.

representative_papers.title: Distributed Representations of Words and Phrases and their Compositionality
representative_papers.abstract:
The article discusses the continuous Skip-gram model for learning distributed vector representations of words and phrases, highlighting its efficiency in capturing syntactic and semantic relationships. It also presents enhancements to improve vector quality and training speed, addresses limitations in representing idiomatic phrases, and introduces techniques like negative sampling for better performance in natural language processing tasks.

Topic: distributional semantics, word embeddings, natural language processing, distributed learning, distributed representations, cognitive science, semantics, language model, text mining, linguistics, language, representation analysis, semantic representation, computational linguistics

representative_papers.title: Glove: Global Vectors for Word Representation
representative_papers.abstract:
The article discusses a new method for learning word vector representations, called Global Vectors for Word Representation (Glove), which combines the strengths of matrix factorization and local context window approaches. It highlights how this model efficiently utilizes statistical information from word co-occurrence matrices to produce meaningful word embeddings that excel in analogy and similarity tasks in natural language processing.

Topic: word embeddings, language resource, computer science, linguistics, computational linguistics, semantic representation, information fusion, language, semantic evaluation, vector space model, word representation, image representation, machine translation, language model, global vectors, deep learning, distributional semantics, text mining, natural language processing, large language model

representative_papers.title: Recursive Deep Models for Semantic Compositionality Over a Sentiment Treebank
representative_papers.abstract:
The article introduces the Sentiment Treebank, a resource designed to enhance the understanding of semantic compositionality in sentiment detection by providing fine-grained labels for parse trees and sentences. It presents the Recursive Neural Tensor Network model, which significantly improves sentiment classification accuracy, achieving state-of-the-art results in both single-sentence and fine-grained sentiment predictions.

Topic: computer science, text mining, language model, natural language processing, treebanks, machine learning, semantic evaluation, vector space model, cognitive science, computational linguistics, data science, knowledge discovery, recursive deep models, semantic compositionality, machine learning research, sentiment treebank, semantic parsing

representative_papers.title: Word Representations: A Simple and General Method for Semi-Supervised Learning
representative_papers.abstract:
The article discusses a method for enhancing the accuracy of supervised natural language processing (NLP) systems by incorporating unsupervised word representations as additional features, evaluating various embedding techniques and their effectiveness in improving named entity recognition (NER) tasks. It highlights the potential for further enhancements by combining different representations and provides resources for accessing the features and code used in the study.

Topic: semantic representation, computer science, linguistics, text mining, natural language processing, language, machine learning, computational linguistics, deep learning, nlp task, machine learning research, semi-supervised learning, distributional semantics, word representations, general method, language learning

representative_papers.title: BERT: Pre-training of Deep Bidirectional Transformers for Language Understanding
representative_papers.abstract:
The article introduces BERT (Bidirectional Encoder Representations from Transformers), a novel language representation model that pre-trains deep bidirectional representations from unlabeled text, enabling state-of-the-art performance across various natural language processing tasks with minimal architectural changes. BERT achieves significant improvements in benchmarks such as GLUE, MultiNLI, and SQuAD, demonstrating its effectiveness in language understanding.

Topic: computer science, language model, natural language processing, language, language engineering, computational linguistics, deep bidirectional transformers, deep learning, machine translation, language understanding

representative_papers.title: Sequence to Sequence Learning with Neural Networks
representative_papers.abstract:
The article discusses a novel end-to-end approach for sequence-to-sequence learning using Deep Neural Networks, specifically employing multilayered Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM) networks to translate between English and French. The method demonstrates significant performance improvements, achieving a BLEU score of 34.8 on the WMT'14 dataset, surpassing traditional phrase-based systems and effectively handling long sentences and word order variations.

Topic: neural networks, knowledge discovery, sparse neural network, neural network (machine learning), sequential learning, computer science, recurrent neural network, deep reinforcement learning, machine learning research, deep learning, sequence modelling, machine vision, natural language processing, natural language generation, machine learning, data science, neural computation, cognitive science, computational intelligence

representative_papers.title: Deep Contextualized Word Representations
representative_papers.abstract:
The article "Deep Contextualized Word Representations" presents a novel approach to generating word embeddings that capture nuanced meanings based on context, enhancing natural language processing tasks such as semantic similarity and text mining. The authors explore the implications of these deep contextualized representations for language learning and computational semantics, contributing to advancements in linguistics and cognitive science.

Topic: language learning, language science, knowledge discovery, word representations, computational semantics, word embeddings, natural language processing, semantic similarity, cognitive science, language model, text mining, linguistics, language, deep learning, semantic representation, computational linguistics

representative_papers.title: Thumbs Up or Thumbs Down? Semantic Orientation Applied to Unsupervised Classification of Reviews
representative_papers.abstract:
The article discusses an unsupervised learning algorithm designed to classify reviews as either recommended or not based on the semantic orientation of phrases containing adjectives and adverbs. By analyzing the average sentiment of these phrases, the algorithm achieves a classification accuracy of 74% across various domains, with performance varying from 84% for automobile reviews to 66% for movie reviews.

Topic: semantic orientation, knowledge discovery, automatic classification, principal component analysis, computer science, machine learning research, text mining, unsupervised classification, affective computing, information retrieval, machine vision, natural language processing, distributional semantics, multimodal sentiment analysis, semantic interpretation, machine learning, linguistics, computational linguistics, cognitive science, semantic evaluation

Topic: neural networks, knowledge discovery, sparse neural network, neural network (machine learning), sequential learning, computer science, recurrent neural network, deep reinforcement learning, machine learning research, deep learning, sequence modelling, machine vision, natural language processing, natural language generation, machine learning, data science, neural computation, cognitive science, computational intelligence

representative_papers_by_period.title: Deep Contextualized Word Representations
representative_papers_by_period.abstract:
The article "Deep Contextualized Word Representations" presents a novel approach to generating word embeddings that capture nuanced meanings based on context, enhancing natural language processing tasks such as semantic similarity and text mining. The authors explore the implications of these deep contextualized representations for language learning and computational semantics, contributing to advancements in linguistics and cognitive science.

Topic: language learning, language science, knowledge discovery, word representations, computational semantics, word embeddings, natural language processing, semantic similarity, cognitive science, language model, text mining, linguistics, language, deep learning, semantic representation, computational linguistics

representative_papers_by_period.title: Thumbs Up or Thumbs Down? Semantic Orientation Applied to Unsupervised Classification of Reviews
representative_papers_by_period.abstract:
The article discusses an unsupervised learning algorithm designed to classify reviews as either recommended or not based on the semantic orientation of phrases containing adjectives and adverbs. By analyzing the average sentiment of these phrases, the algorithm achieves a classification accuracy of 74% across various domains, with performance varying from 84% for automobile reviews to 66% for movie reviews.

Topic: semantic orientation, knowledge discovery, automatic classification, principal component analysis, computer science, machine learning research, text mining, unsupervised classification, affective computing, information retrieval, machine vision, natural language processing, distributional semantics, multimodal sentiment analysis, semantic interpretation, machine learning, linguistics, computational linguistics, cognitive science, semantic evaluation
